titleStmt.title: The Irish treaty, or the last and best intelligence from Ireland; being a perfect relation of the most remarkable occurrents in that kingdome, since the Lord Taffes going over thither with a commission from his Majesty to treat with the rebels there. In which is contained an exact relation of the said treaty at Trimme, between the Marquesse of Ormond, and Sir Francis Willoughby, for his Majesty, and the Lord Neuterfield and others in the behalfe of the rebels. As also a continuation of the victorious successe of the Protestant forces in severall parts of Ireland, since the breaking off and conclusion of the said treaty. In a letter to the Lady Rogers.
titleStmt.author: Brimpahir, George.

titleStmt.title: The Irish treaty, or the last and best intelligence from Ireland; being a perfect relation of the most remarkable occurrents in that kingdome, since the Lord Taffes going over thither with a commission from his Majesty to treat with the rebels there. In which is contained an exact relation of the said treaty at Trimme, between the Marquesse of Ormond, and Sir Francis Willoughby, for his Majesty, and the Lord Neuterfield and others in the behalfe of the rebels. As also a continuation of the victorious successe of the Protestant forces in severall parts of Ireland, since the breaking off and conclusion of the said treaty. In a letter to the Lady Rogers.
titleStmt.author: Brimpahir, George.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by T. Harper for H Shepheard, and are to be sold by G. Tomlinson, at his shop on Ludgate-hill,

notesStmt.note: Signed and dated at end : George Brimpahir [pseud.]: Dublin : July 2, 1643.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
